docs.lead_paragraph: At Pomona College, dining hall employees were fired after questions about their residency status, prompting a debate over what it means to be a liberal college.

headline.seo: Immigrant Worker Firings Unsettle Pomona College
headline.main: Immigrant Worker Firings Unsettle a College Campus
headline.print_headline: Immigrant Worker Firings Unsettle a College Campus

docs.abstract: Incident in which Pomona College officials dismissed seventeen long-time dining hall employees over questions about their residency status has provoked a fierce on-campus debate over the role a liberal arts college should play regarding immigration; some students, faculty and alumni have accused the administration of betraying the college's ideals.
docs.snippet: At Pomona College, dining hall employees were fired after questions about their residency status, prompting a debate over what it means to be a liberal college.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Cornelius was the smooth-voiced television host who brought black music and culture into America’s living rooms when he created the dance show “Soul Train.”

headline.seo: Don Cornelius, ‘Soul Train’ Creator, Is Dead
headline.main: Don Cornelius, ‘Soul Train’ Creator, Is Dead at 75
headline.print_headline: Don Cornelius, ‘Soul Train’ Creator, Is Dead at 75

docs.abstract: Don Cornelius, creator and host of Soul Train dance show, dies at age 75.
docs.snippet: Mr. Cornelius was the smooth-voiced television host who brought black music and culture into America’s living rooms when he created the dance show “Soul Train.”

docs.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS - On a three-hour flight from Minneapolis to Florida, where he picked up the state's 50 delegates Tuesday night in a big primary victory, an ebullient Mitt Romney came to the back of his private plane to chat with his traveling press corps.

headline.main: Despite Big Victory, Romney Won't Let Up on Gingrich

docs.abstract: Mitt Romney comes off a Florida victory questioning Newt Gingrich's conservative credentials.
docs.snippet: Mitt Romney comes off a Florida victory questioning Newt Gingrich's conservative credentials.

headline.main: Will the I.R.S. Be Busy Next Year?

docs.abstract: The outcome of the presidential election might help determine how many audits the Internal Revenue Service conducts and whether they're aimed more at individuals or corporations, if historical patterns hold, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: The outcome of the presidential election might help determine how many audits the Internal Revenue Service conducts and whether they're aimed more at individuals or corporations, if historical patterns hold, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline.main: Will the I.R.S. Be Busy Next Year?

docs.abstract: The outcome of the presidential election might help determine how many audits the Internal Revenue Service conducts and whether they're aimed more at individuals or corporations, if historical patterns hold, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal budget deficit will remain over $1 trillion, the Congressional Budget Office said.

headline.seo: Under Status Quo, Deficit Would Decline, Budget Office Says
headline.main: Budget Deficit Tops $1 Trillion, but Is Falling, Report Says
headline.print_headline: Economy Is Projected To Remain Sluggish

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office says the economy will remain sluggish, with high unemployment, and that the federal budget will exceed $1 trillion in 2012 for the fourth consecutive year; says deficit will be $1.1 trillion, about $200 billion less than in 2011.
docs.snippet: The federal budget deficit will remain over $1 trillion, the Congressional Budget Office said.
